awd_titl_txt: NNA Track 2: Collaborative Research: Planning for Climate Resiliency Amid Changing Culture, Technology, Economics, and Governance
awd_abstract_narration:
Navigating the New Arctic (NNA) is one of NSF's 10 Big Ideas. NNA projects address convergence scientific challenges in the rapidly changing Arctic. The Arctic research is needed to inform the economy, security and resilience of the Nation, the larger region and the globe. NNA empowers new research partnerships from local to international scales, diversifies the next generation of Arctic researchers, and integrates the co-production of knowledge. This award fulfills part of that aim.

This project is taking a unique approach to investigating what is needed to enable subsistence communities in the Arctic to remain sustainable in the future: questioning the common assumption that climate impacts and sea ice loss are the most important changes impacting subsistence activities in the Arctic.  The group will broadly consider a set of interconnected factors and feedbacks, including changing culture, technology, economics, and governance in addition to climate. The proposal includes a clear plans to integrate co-production of knowledge and to capture the linkage between researchers and native communities. This project may lead to a holistic approach to the evolution of subsistence living in the Arctic and to create a community of practice including Arctic peoples with traditional knowledge and university-trained scientists.


This project is exploring a series of hypotheses designed to stress-test assumptions about the role of rapid physical environmental change in disrupting traditional ways of life for Arctic coastal communities. A community of practice composed of academics from various disciplines and residents of the Arctic communities of Utqiagvik and Kotzebue is being established to consider a central guiding question: How can Alaskan subsistence communities best prepare for and adapt to climate change in a world where nothing else is static? The outcomes of this work include tools and methods for understanding motives of climate adaptations in Alaska Native communities and assessing their effectiveness. The project is also coproducing a plan for future research aimed at improving community and individual resilience in the face of impending Arctic changes

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this planning grant was to discuss and plan research efforts relevant to community needs with members of the Arctic communities of Kotzebue and Utqiagvik. In particular we focued on the needs of subsistence resource users who are being impacted by rapid environmental change.

We met and discussed research priorities and needs with a wide range of individuals in each community. We learned that, although physical climate change is highly disruptive to subsistence activities, many other aspects of health, wellness, cultural identity, infrastructure, and economy may be greater threats to subsistence lifestyles and cultural continuity. These other threats may be greater priorities for knowledge generation than environmental change. We also found that that needs articulated by community members spanned a range of knowledge generation and sharing needs that was broader than what is typically addressed by project-driven research. Some of these needs would be best addressed by outreach, because the knowledge is already known, but needs to be shared better. Others would be suited to a model of expert consulation because the knoweldge is known but must be tailored to site-specific conditions to be useful. Only a smaller subset of articulated needs would be best met by novel basic research, and these typically were of a nature that would require a series of coordinated efforts over a long period of time, such as developing improved predictions of environmental change or improved approaches to health and wellness. Across all types of knowledge needs there was a clear need for better coordination at a local level, liasonship between scientific activities and communiteis, and better incorporation of local knowledge.

The outcome of this planning project is the coordination of a group of community members and scientists who now seek to implement improved models for community-science engagement that address the needs identified. Particularly the group is seeking to implement activities akin to Cooperative Extension Networks that could result in a tigher connection between knowledge generation and end users, more targeted allocation of research funding, and improved knowledge accessibilty for stakeholders. Overall these outcomes are likely to contribute to ongoing improvements in the value derived from our national investments in knowledge generation.
